body:
Thanks for the change. Is this intended to be a work in progress towards a more generic bulk uploader?

Please avoid postfix operators. According to SIP 18, "Postfix operators interact poorly with semicolon inference. Most programmers avoid them for this reason." (http://docs.scala-lang.org/sips/completed/modularizing-language-features.html)

This is more of a random data uploaded, with option for generic bulk uploading. It is just easier now for a developed to create data for his application. 

I have fixed the Postfix operators..

the fix is giving an error message. As in mongodb you are not allowed to have a dot in the key. We could have a string replace on the api end for the users but i think it is overload. 

API documentation should be updated also. 

http://docs.mongodb.org/manual/reference/limits/#Restrictions-on-Field-Names
Looking good. Thanks for the contribution, @roninio!

The fix looks very clean now. Thanks a lot! Definitely appreciate your effort.

On a second thought, there are more than one places that need this check. We think it would be more proper to implement this check in the form validation (defined in https://github.com/PredictionIO/PredictionIO/blob/develop/servers/api/app/io/prediction/api/Attributes.scala) instead. What do you think?

To avoid too much back-and-forth, we can decide on a design first before any actual implementation is done. :)
Thanks!
Awesome. Thanks!
Thanks!

Thanks! @jfeinstein10
Actually would you merge with PredictionIO:trending_algo branch locally before make a pull request?

also, I know TrendingTest.scala is not doing anything now but could you fix its compilation error and change to dummy check so that at least the test can compile and pass?
- in
  https://github.com/jfeinstein10/PredictionIO/blob/ff20438728e2e0ae18f6a80fc623adecbd9e9b53/process/engines/itemrec/algorithms/hadoop/scalding/trending/src/test/scala/io/prediction/algorithms/scalding/itemrec/trending/TrendingTest.scala#L101

should be test() instead of testWithMerge()

## 

https://github.com/jfeinstein10/PredictionIO/blob/ff20438728e2e0ae18f6a80fc623adecbd9e9b53/process/engines/itemrec/algorithms/hadoop/scalding/trending/src/test/scala/io/prediction/algorithms/scalding/itemrec/trending/TrendingTest.scala#L43
Still getting a flow error when running the test, but I'll address it later tonight
The DataPreparatorTest is failing now that I removed a lot of arguments, I'll add them back as optional arguments for now.
Thanks Leo. Please update the code according to the comment above. And please ignore the travis warning. Prediction.IO team will fix it.

@yipjustin 

Thanks for the explanations. :)
I'm very happy with the oportunity of helping this great project.

I will fix the code and push again.

Thanks Tom. Looks good.

One more styling comment: Try your best to keep scala code within 80 columns, and java within 100.

Will merge it once this is fixed.

Hi Ionel,

It seems to me that this pull request is invalid. Would you mind explain a bit? :)

Justin
Apologies, wanted to update my own fork.

Hi Eugene,

The code definitely looks cleaner. Before I merge this PR, would you mind signing our contributor agreement?

http://prediction.io/cla

Thanks.

Justin
Will do soon, thanks.
Hope I did it correctly.

Looks great. Will merge it tomorrow when I go to the office.

Thanks for contributing!

Hi Leo,

We have significantly refactored our codebase to allow engineers to build and customize machine learning algorithm efficiently. We have also migrated our storage to make it more generic. The bulk-uploading code in this PR needs to be update. 

We have another open [JIRA ticket](https://predictionio.atlassian.net/browse/PDIO-358) describing a high level design. Are you interested in working on it?

Justin
Thanks for updating the notes.

Hi Justin,

First of all, congratulations for the new PIO 0.8.
In a few days I will start to try this with our upcoming newsletter
recommendation tool.

About ht the JIRA ticket, I'm absolutely interested. :)
In part to learn more about Scala and PIO, on the other hand to make
possible to others import large data.

What's the best way to do this: update the existing code on old PR or
create a new one with a new fork of PIO 0.8?

Thanks for the chance to contribute.

Léo Hackin
leohackin@gmail.com
http://www.leohackin.com.br
Twitter: @leohackin

Hi Leo,

Thanks for your interest.

As the new uploading tool will be dramatically different from the one for
0.7, I think it makes sense to create a new PR.

Just want to get a rough estimate, can we have a ETA? (no pressure :)

Justin

Hey Justin,

I forgot to add this link to the readme: http://docs.prediction.io/0.8.1/install/. Just did it.

Was wondering if you wanted to merge again?

Gaurang

Hi Justin,

Sorry for the delay.

Perfect. I will create the new PR.
About the ETA, the sprint to test the PIO 0.8 starts on begin of december.

So, an reasonable ETA is the end of december. Maybe a little before. ;)

![screen shot 2014-12-03 at 9 03 13 pm](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/6980665/5293905/d513351a-7b2f-11e4-8701-58b60ac10a4e.png)

Image of RSIIndicator run with (1, 5, 22) day periods on large data set.
Updated with edits.

Gaurang, please sync your repo to the latest prediction io repository.

The "scala-stock" directory has been moved to "examples/experimental/scala-stock".
Repo still has some changes remaining.
Thanks for the PR! Would you mind signing our CLA (http://prediction.io/cla) before I merge this?
Ah sure, didn't realize that would be required for docs but it's all one repo under Apache 2 I suppose. Done!
Thanks @ches !

Thanks for the PR. Could you please sign the contributor's agreement first before I merge?

Thanks @pawel-n Code looks great! I made a few wording changes and rewrote our other loop to use your confirm method which is really handy to have. I also moved a few things around to make sure our Docker install path remains interactive free.

I love how are script is getting better every day. If you have any more suggestions please let us know.  We will be rolling out these changes on install.prediction.io shorty!
Thanks for the fix @leandrosilva ! Before we can merge your PR, would you mind signing our CLA (http://prediction.io/cla) please?
Done. :)
Thanks @leandrosilva !

Any idea why this isn't reflected in the contributor graph? https://github.com/PredictionIO/PredictionIO/graphs/contributors
Odd indeed. According to https://help.github.com/articles/i-don-t-see-myself-in-the-repository-contributors-graph/, your name should have shown up.
Thanks!
Thanks!

Hey, I just realized your commits are associated with your gmail.com e-mail address. You will need to associate that e-mail address with your GitHub account for you to show up on the contributor graph. Once you've done it, GitHub should update automatically.
Thanks!
Brilliant. Thanks!
Oh yeah! Thanks fixed it.
Thanks!
Thanks @mkausik !

Hi @ArturSoler,
creating a separate model for each category is not ideal solution because
- duplicates many model if many categories
- should also support query by multiple categories, for example,
  {"user": "1", "num": 4, "categories": ["action", "adventure"]})
  Some reference you can take a look:
  http://docs.prediction.io/templates/recommendation/blacklist-items/
  http://docs.prediction.io/templates/similarproduct/quickstart/
  https://github.com/PredictionIO/template-scala-parallel-ecommercerecommendation

Thanks!

Looking good! Would you mind applying the change also to all other downloaded files (Spark, Elasticsearch, and HBase), and submit the PR against the master branch instead? That way the change will be immediately deployed live to https://install.prediction.io/install.sh. Thanks!

how about i silently delete those files?

Best Regards,
Nicholas

Hi @k4hoo,

I understand the issue and have updated the example to use a single model. I have also updated the `Query` to support multiple categories, as you suggested.

Thanks for your pointers, they have made this much easier. Let me know if there's any other issue.

Artur
Thanks @ramanaopensource !
